data.title: 100 Classic Vietnamese Last Names: With Meanings
data.meta_description: Our information-packed list includes 100 Vietnamese last names, including their origins, unique meanings, and accurate pronunciations.
data.text:
Vietnam has a fascinating history that includes a thousand-year Chinese occupation and modern-day independence. This unique history has certainly influenced Vietnamese last names over time, making it essential to recognize the particular differences to understand them better.

Our fascinating guide ahead has all the backstory you could ask for and more. You‚Äôll discover their origin, variations, and famous namesakes. Along the way, you‚Äôll come to appreciate the traditions behind Vietnamese family names and those who use them.

Gender

Style

100 Popular Vietnamese Surnames

These Vietnamese last names pack a punch when it comes to meaning and tradition.

√Åi

Like many Vietnamese last names, √Åi first appeared in China out of a surname meaning ‚Äúto love,‚Äù ‚Äúto be fond of,‚Äù ‚Äúto like,‚Äù or ‚Äúaffection.‚Äù It can also mean ‚Äúmugwort‚Äù and is associated with similar Mandarin and Taiwanese surnames.

Origin: Vietnamese, Chinese

Meaning: To love

Pronunciation: AEY

Namesakes: A√¨ Qƒ´ng, a Chinese poet known for Dayanhe‚ÄîMy Nanny. Ai Baojun, the Vice Mayor of Shanghai from 2012 to 2015.

Popularity: √Åi ranked 610th worldwide, is primarily used in China, and ranked 83rd in Vietnam in 2014.

Anh

Anh comes from the Sino-Vietnamese ‚Äúanh,‚Äù meaning ‚Äúpetal,‚Äù ‚Äúflower,‚Äù ‚Äúbrave,‚Äù or ‚Äúhero.‚Äù Some associated Anh with the Chinese Yƒ´ng, which sometimes means ‚Äúintellectual‚Äù and ‚Äúbright.‚Äù

Origin: Vietnamese

Meaning: Flower, petal

Pronunciation: AEYNH

Variations: An

Namesakes: Anh Do, a Vietnamese-Australian writer and winner of the 2017 People‚Äôs Choice Award.

Popularity: Anh ranked 804th worldwide and is mainly used in Vietnam, ranking 23rd in 2014.

Bach

Bach is included in many Vietnamese surnames used by the Chinese community in Vietnam. In addition to ‚Äúwhite,‚Äù it also means ‚Äúsnowy,‚Äù ‚Äúpure,‚Äù and ‚Äúto make clear.‚Äù Bach is known as Bai in Chinese and Baek in Korean.

Origin: Vietnamese, Chinese

Meaning: White

Pronunciation: BAAK

Variations: Baek, Baik

Namesakes: Bach Hung Khang, a Vietnamese scientist and pioneer in information technology. Tr·∫ßn B·∫°ch ƒê·∫±ng, a Vietnamese communist leader known for the book V√°n b√†i l·∫≠t ng·ª≠a.

Popularity: Bach is rare worldwide and primarily used in Vietnam, where it ranked 114th in 2014.

Ban

Ban is derived from Mi, a royal surname dating back to the ancient Chinese State of Chu. It‚Äôs also related to the occupation of a ‚Äúhelper,‚Äù ‚Äúsupporter,‚Äù or for something living in a forest.

Origin: Vietnamese, Chinese

Meaning: Of the forest

Pronunciation: BAAN

Variations: Pan

Namesakes: Ban Biao, a 1st-century Chinese historian known for beginning the Book of Han.

Popularity: Ban ranked 1,417th worldwide, is mostly used in China, and ranked 213th in Vietnam in 2014.

Bao

Bao is taken from the Sino-Vietnamese ‚Äúb·∫£o,‚Äù meaning ‚Äútreasure‚Äù or ‚Äújewel.‚Äù Its other meanings include ‚Äúbundle,‚Äù ‚Äúpackage,‚Äù and ‚Äúguarantee.‚Äù

Origin: Vietnamese, Chinese

Meaning: Treasure

Pronunciation: BAOW

Variations: Pao

Namesakes: Bao Yingying, a Chinese saber fencer and silver medalist at the 2008 Summer Olympics. Bao Bei‚Äôer, a Chinese actor known for Welcome to Shama Town (2010).

Popularity: Bao ranked 220th worldwide, is mainly used in China, and ranked 20th in Vietnam in 2014.

Bong

Bong derives from the Chinese Hu√°ng, meaning ‚Äúyellow,‚Äù and W√°ng, meaning ‚Äúking.‚Äù It even appears in Korea, where it means ‚Äúmythical bird.‚Äù

Origin: Vietnamese, Chinese

Meaning: King

Pronunciation: BOHNG

Variations: Pong

Namesakes: Diana Bong Siong Lin, a Malay wushu taolu coach and bronze medalist at the 2006 Asian Games. Bong Chang-won, a South Korean wrestler who competed at the 1960 Summer Olympics.

Popularity: Bong is rare worldwide, primarily used in Malaysia, and ranked 308th in Vietnam in 2014.

B√πi

B√πi‚Äôs original Chinese meaning refers to a ‚Äúlong and flowing garment.‚Äù It appears as Pei in Chinese and Bae in Korean. B√πi may also be related to the Vietnamese ‚Äúbui,‚Äù meaning ‚Äúcloud.‚Äù

Origin: Vietnamese, Chinese

Meaning: Long flowing (garment)

Pronunciation: BUW-ee

Namesakes: B√πi ƒê√¨nh Dƒ©nh, the Ambassador Extraordinary and Plenipotentiary of Vietnam to the Russian Federation from 2007 to 2011. B√πi T·∫•n Tr∆∞·ªùng, a Vietnamese footballer for H√† N·ªôi.

Popularity: Bui ranked 260th worldwide and is mostly used in Vietnam, ranking 9th in 2023.

Cao

Cao originates in Mandarin Chinese, meaning ‚Äúconduct‚Äù and ‚Äúbehavior.‚Äù Cao ranks 30th among popular surnames in mainland China and 58th in Taiwan in 2019.

Origin: Vietnamese, Chinese

Meaning: Grasp

Pronunciation: KAOW

Variations: T√†o

Namesakes: Cao Lu, a Chinese singer with the South Korean girl group Fiestar. Cao Yupeng, a Chinese snooker player who won the 2011 Asian Under-21 Championship.

Popularity: Cao ranked 58th worldwide, is mainly used in China, and ranked 24th in Vietnam in 2014.

Chang

Chang means ‚Äúconstant‚Äù or ‚Äúoften‚Äù and is linked to the Japanese Ch≈ç. It‚Äôs a more modern form of the original Vietnamese Tr∆∞∆°ng. Chang was first used by descendants of Chang Yi, who lived during the reign of the Yellow Emperor.

Origin: Vietnamese, Chinese

Meaning: Constant

Pronunciation: CHAHNG

Variations: Th∆∞·ªùng

Namesakes: Chang Liang-jen, the Taiwanese ROC Representative to Indonesia from 2014 to 2016. Chang Kai-Chen (known as Kelly Chang), a Taiwanese tennis player who peaked at 82nd in 2014.

Popularity: Chang ranked 147th worldwide, is primarily used in China, and ranked 10th in South Korea in 2014.

Ch√™

Ch√™ is most common among the southern Vietnamese Cham. It can mean ‚Äúcarriage‚Äù or ‚Äúcart‚Äù in Chinese and originated with Che Ou, a famous ancient astrologer.

Origin: Vietnamese

Meaning: Carriage

Pronunciation: CHEAY

Variations: Chae

Namesakes: Che Runqiu, a Chinese-Hong Kong footballer for Tai Po. Che Yongli, a Chinese actress known for A Singing Fairy (2010).

Popularity: Che ranked 660th worldwide, is primarily used in China, and ranked 262nd in Vietnam in 2014.

Chim

Besides ‚Äúbird,‚Äù Chim means ‚ÄúGod will judge‚Äù in Vietnamese. Its origin is also Cambodian, where it means ‚Äúpracticing divination.‚Äù Chim‚Äôs Chinese equivalent is Zhan.

Origin: Vietnamese, Chinese

Meaning: Bird

Pronunciation: CHIHM

Namesakes: Chim Pui-chung, a member of the Legislative Council of Hong Kong from 1991 to 1997. Jim Chim Sui-man (born ZhƒÅn Ru√¨w√©n), a Hong Kong actor known for You Shoot, I Shoot (2001).

Popularity: Chim is rare worldwide, mainly used in Cambodia, and ranked 380th in 2014.

C√¥ng

C√¥ng means ‚Äúfair,‚Äù ‚Äúequitable,‚Äù and ‚Äúpublic‚Äù in Sino-Vietnamese. It‚Äôs a Chinese surname found in a particular community in Wendeng, China. C√¥ng also appears in Japan, Korea, and Mongolia.

Origin: Vietnamese, Chinese

Meaning: Fair

Pronunciation: KHONG

Variations: Cung

Namesakes: Cong Peiwu, the Chinese Ambassador to Canada since 2019. Cong Yanxia, a Chinese handball player who competed at the 1996 Summer Olympics.

Popularity: C√¥ng ranked 1,072nd worldwide, is primarily used in China, and ranked 85th in 2014.

C√∫c

Like many Vietnamese family names, C√∫c has multiple meanings. It means ‚Äúbent,‚Äù ‚Äúcrooked,‚Äù ‚Äútune,‚Äù and ‚Äúsong.‚Äù It also refers to Chrysanthemums, a Mayan name meaning ‚ÄúQuetzal bird.‚Äù

Origin: Vietnamese

Meaning: Bent

Pronunciation: KOOK

Popularity: C√∫c is rare worldwide, mainly used in Guatemala, and ranked 458th in Vietnam in 2014.

C∆∞·ªùng

C∆∞·ªùng‚Äôs meanings include ‚Äústrong,‚Äù plus ‚Äútough‚Äù or ‚Äúresilient.‚Äù It derives from the Han Vietnamese language, where it also means ‚Äústubborn‚Äù and ‚Äúunyielding.‚Äù C∆∞·ªùng is sometimes a nickname for kids who have great prospects in life.

Origin: Vietnamese

Meaning: Tough

Pronunciation: KUUNG

Variations: Chuong

Namesakes: Cuong Ngo, a Vietnamese director known for The Golden Pin (2009). Cuong Vu, a Vietnamese-American jazz trumpeter and the first Vietnamese-American to win a Grammy Award.

Popularity: C∆∞·ªùng is rare worldwide and primarily used in Vietnam, where it ranked 180th in 2014.

ƒê·∫∑ng

ƒê·∫∑ng means both ‚Äúparty‚Äù and ‚Äúassociation.‚Äù It also refers to the Clan of Man in the State of Deng during the Chinese Spring and Autumn period.

Origin: Vietnamese, Chinese

Meaning: Association

Pronunciation: DAENG

Variations: Deng

Namesakes: ƒê·∫∑ng Th·ªã Ng·ªçc Th·ªãnh, the Vice President of Vietnam from 2016 to 2021. ƒê·∫∑ng Minh, a Vietnamese director, awarded the Nikkei Asia Prize for Culture in 1999.

Popularity: ƒê·∫∑ng ranked 292nd worldwide and is primarily used in Vietnam, ranking 15th in 2014.

Danh

Dang means ‚Äúfamous‚Äù in both Vietnamese and Chinese. It also means ‚Äúname‚Äù and is quite popular in Vietnam but not found as much beyond China.

Origin: Vietnamese, Chinese

Meaning: Famous

Pronunciation: DAEYN

Namesakes: Danh Quach, a Vietnamese-American businessman known in Orange County‚Äôs Little Saigon. Danh V√µ, a Vietnamese artist who won the 2012 Hugo Boss Prize.

Popularity: Danh is rare worldwide and mostly used in Vietnam, where it ranked 5th in 2014.

ƒê√†o

Like other names on our list, ƒê√†o‚Äôs meanings don‚Äôt always match. It can describe ‚Äúpottery‚Äù and ‚Äúpleased.‚Äù ƒê√†o is also the name of an ethnic group from China who arrived in Vietnam in the 12th- and 13th-centuries.

Origin: Vietnamese, Chinese

Meaning: Pottery

Pronunciation: DAOW

Namesakes: ƒê√†o VƒÉn Phong, a Vietnamese footballer for Sanna Kh√°nh H√≤a BVN. Julie C. Dao, a Vietnamese-American fantasy writer known for Forest of a Thousand Lanterns (2017).

Popularity: ƒê√†o ranked 651st worldwide and is mainly used in Vietnam, ranking 26th in 2014.

Di√™m

Di√™m means ‚Äúmysterious,‚Äù ‚Äúsubtle,‚Äù and ‚Äúexquisite.‚Äù It‚Äôs also a girl‚Äôs name in Vietnam, where it means ‚Äúbeautiful,‚Äù ‚Äúcharming,‚Äù or ‚Äúkind-hearted.‚Äù

Origin: Vietnamese

Meaning: Mysterious

Pronunciation: DYEM

Variations: Dieu

Namesakes: Ryan Diem, an American football player for the Indianapolis Colts.

Popularity: Di√™m is rare worldwide and primarily used in Vietnam, where it ranked 257th in 2014.

Di·ªáp

Di·ªáp‚Äôs Chinese-associated meanings include ‚Äúto be in harmony,‚Äù ‚Äúleaf,‚Äù and ‚Äúpage.‚Äù It also refers to a specific time in Chinese history.

Origin: Vietnamese, Chinese

Meaning: In harmony

Pronunciation: DEE-yehp

Popularity: Diep is rare worldwide and mostly used in Vietnam, ranking 119th in 2014.

ƒêinh

ƒêinh means ‚Äúpalace‚Äù or ‚Äútemple‚Äù in Vietnamese, along with ‚Äúboy‚Äù or ‚Äúman‚Äù in Chinese. It also refers to a 10th-century Vietnamese imperial dynasty, which is why it‚Äôs a unisex name for noble babies.

Origin: Vietnamese, Chinese

Meaning: Palace

Pronunciation: DIHN

Namesakes: Dinh Xuan Luu, the Vietnamese ambassador to Israel since 2009. Viet D. Dinh, the Vietnamese-American Assistant Attorney General of the U.S. from 2001 to 2003.

Popularity: ƒêinh ranked 642nd worldwide and is mainly used in Vietnam, where it ranked 19th in 2014.

Do

Do is the Vietnamese equivalent of the Chinese Du, first referring to a ‚Äúdescendant of the Tao-Tang tribe.‚Äù Do appears as Tu in Taiwan, To in Hong Kong, and Tou in Macau.

Origin: Vietnamese, Chinese

Meaning: Birchleaf pear

Pronunciation: DOH

Namesakes: Khoa Do, a Vietnamese-Australian director, awarded the Young Australian of the Year Award in 2005. ƒê·ªó Ng·ªçc Y·∫øn, a Vietnamese-American newspaper publisher who founded the Nguoi Viet Daily News.

Popularity: Do ranked 342nd worldwide and is primarily used in Vietnam, ranking 11th in 2014.

Duc

Duc comes from the Sino-Vietnamese ƒë·ª©c, meaning ‚Äúvirtue.‚Äù As a boy‚Äôs name, it means ‚Äúmoral‚Äù and ‚Äúgood‚Äù and is the name for several locations in Vietnam.

Origin: Vietnamese

Meaning: Virtuous

Pronunciation: DUUK

Namesakes: Catherine Duc, a Vietnamese-Australian composer featured on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation‚Äôs ABC Jazz. D·ª•c ƒê·ª©c, the Emperor of Vietnam from July 20th to July 23rd, 1883.

Popularity: Duc is rare worldwide and mostly used in Vietnam by 1 in 706 people as of 2014.

Duy

Duy is a Vietnamese surname and a first name deriving from Chinese, meaning ‚Äúdimension.‚Äù Duy also means ‚Äúvirtuous‚Äù and takes inspiration from an early 20th-century emperor.

Origin: Vietnamese

Meaning: Dimension

Pronunciation: DWEY

Namesakes: Duy T√¢n, the 11th emperor of the Nguy·ªÖn dynasty in Vietnam from 1907 and 1916.

Popularity: Duy is rare worldwide and mainly used in Vietnam by 1 in 566 people as of 2014.

Giang

Giang is the Vietnamese equivalent of the Chinese Jiang, meaning ‚Äúriver.‚Äù The structure among Vietnamese last names includes a ‚Äúg‚Äù being pronounced as ‚Äúz‚Äù or ‚Äúj‚Äù when followed by ‚Äúe‚Äù or ‚Äúi.‚Äù

Origin: Vietnamese, Chinese

Meaning: River

Pronunciation: ZANG

Namesakes: Tr√† Giang, a Vietnamese actress known for 17th Parallel, Nights and Days (1973). Emil Le Giang, a Slovak footballer for Union Wallsee.

Popularity: Giang is rare worldwide and primarily used in Vietnam.

Gi√°p

Gi√°p sometimes refers to the ‚Äúname of a district in Henan.‚Äù It stems from Chinese, meaning ‚Äúthe first heavenly stem.‚Äù

Origin: Vietnamese, Chinese

Meaning: Henan district (China)

Pronunciation: ZYAP

Popularity: Gi√°p is rare worldwide and primarily used in Vietnam.

Hai

In Vietnamese and Chinese, Hai means ‚Äúsea‚Äù or ‚Äúocean.‚Äù It appears as He in Chinese and Ha in Korean.

Origin: Vietnamese, Chinese

Meaning: Ocean

Pronunciation: AEY

Namesakes: Hai Xia, a Chinese news anchor for China Central Television. Hai Rui, a Chinese basketball player for the Shanghai Sharks.

Popularity: Hai is rare worldwide and mainly used in China, where it ranked 293rd in 2013.

H√≤a

H√≤a means‚Äùflower‚Äù in Sino-Vietnamese, while it means‚Äútogether‚Äù and ‚Äúharmonious‚Äù in Chinese. Hoa is also the name of an ethnic Chinese minority group in Vietnam, also found in the Americas.

Origin: Vietnamese, Chinese

Meaning: Flower

Pronunciation: HOH-ah

Popularity: H√≤a is rare worldwide and primarily used in Vietnam by 1 in 660 people in 2014.

Ho√†ng

Ho√†ng means ‚Äúyellow‚Äù and ‚Äúto fall through‚Äù in Chinese. It sometimes appears as Huang and was changed to Hu·ª≥nh in South Vietnam due to Lord Nguy·ªÖn Ho√†ng.

Origin: Vietnamese, Chinese

Meaning: Yellow

Pronunciation: HWAENG

Variations: Ho√†ng, Hu·ª≥nh

Namesakes: Ho√†ng Anh Tu·∫•n, a Vietnamese weightlifter and silver medalist at the 2005 Junior World Championships. Ho√†ng Trung H·∫£i, the Deputy Prime Minister of Vietnam from 2007 to 2016.

Popularity: Ho√†ng is rare worldwide and primarily used in Vietnam, where it‚Äôs currently used by 5.1% of the population.

H·ª©a

H·ª©a means ‚Äúto allow,‚Äù ‚Äúto promise,‚Äù or ‚Äúto praise.‚Äù It sometimes refers to the Chinese people and also means ‚Äúflower.‚Äù The Cantonese equivalents are Wah and Fa.

Origin: Vietnamese, Chinese

Meaning: To permit

Pronunciation: HUW-ah

Namesakes: Hua Jianmin, the president of the China National School of Administration. Hua Chenyu, a Chinese pop singer appearing in Singer 2018.

Popularity: H·ª©a ranks 28th on the Song dynasty-era Hundred Family Surnames in China in 2023.

Hung

Hung means ‚Äúcourageous‚Äù and ‚Äúheroic,‚Äù as well as ‚Äúbrave‚Äù and ‚Äúmanly‚Äù for a boy. Hung is also the name of a Viet-Muong language in Laos.

Origin: Vietnamese

Meaning: Courageous

Pronunciation: HUHNG

Namesakes: Xiong Dailin (known as Lynn Hung), a Hong Kong fashion model and the 4th highest-paid model in Greater China in 2009. William Hung, a Hong Kong former singer associated with American Idol.

Popularity: Hung is rare worldwide and mainly used in Vietnam by 1 in 699 in 2014.

Huynh

In Chinese, Hu·ª≥nh means ‚Äúyellow,‚Äù ‚Äúgolden,‚Äù or ‚Äúhaving the color of gold.‚Äù It currently ranks 7th in China and 5th in Vietnam, while it goes by Hwang in Korea.

Origin: Vietnamese, Chinese

Meaning: Older brother

Pronunciation: HOOWN

Variations: Ho√†ng

Namesakes: Hu·ª≥nh T·∫•n Ph√°t, the Deputy Prime Minister from 1976 to 1982. Carol Huynh, a Canadian freestyle wrestler and gold medalist at the 2008 Beijing Olympics.

Popularity: Huynh is rare worldwide and primarily used in Vietnam, where it ranked 5th in 2023.

Ky

Ky was originally a Chinese surname meaning ‚Äúto hope for.‚Äù It‚Äôs also a nickname for the Chinese Hebei province.

Origin: Vietnamese, Chinese

Meaning: Good luck

Pronunciation: KEE

Namesakes: Ky Nam Le Duc, a Vietnamese-Canadian director who won Best Canadian Short Film at the 2009 CFC Worldwide Short Film Festival. Ky Rodwell, an Australian rugby league footballer for the Parramatta Eels.

Popularity: Ky is rare worldwide and mostly used in Vietnam, ranking 265th in 2023.

Kh√°nh

Kh√°nh means ‚Äúto congratulate‚Äù or ‚Äúcelebrate.‚Äù It‚Äôs also a Turkish boy‚Äôs name derived from Khagan, meaning ‚Äúprince,‚Äù ‚Äúsovereign,‚Äù and ‚Äúruler.‚Äù

Origin: Vietnamese, Turkish

Meaning: Congratulate

Pronunciation: KAEN

Namesakes: Kh√°nh Ly, a Vietnamese-American singer who performed songs by the composer Tr·ªãnh C√¥ng S∆°n.

Popularity: Kh√°nh is rare worldwide and mainly used in Vietnam, where it ranked 98th in 2023.

Khi

Though Sino-Vietnamese, Khi is based on the Late Middle Chinese ‚Äúkhj…®jh,‚Äù meaning ‚Äúair‚Äù or ‚Äúgad.‚Äù It‚Äôs also the Vietnamese version of ‚Äúchi,‚Äù referring to the ‚Äúvital energy‚Äù of the universe.

Origin: Vietnamese, Chinese

Meaning: Air

Pronunciation: KEE

Popularity: Khi is very rare worldwide and primarily used in Vietnam.

Khuu

Khuu first appeared as the Chinese Qiu, meaning ‚Äúautumn.‚Äù In Vietnamese, it describes everything from a ‚Äúmound‚Äù and ‚Äúhillock‚Äù to a ‚Äúgrave.‚Äù

Origin: Vietnamese, Chinese

Meaning: Mound

Pronunciation: KOO

Popularity: Khuu is rare worldwide and primarily used in Vietnam, ranking 253rd in 2023.

Kieu

Kieu comes from the Sino-Vietnamese ‚Äúki·ªÅu,‚Äù meaning ‚Äúseductive,‚Äù ‚Äúspoiled,‚Äù and ‚Äúloveable.‚Äù It can also mean ‚Äútall,‚Äù ‚Äúgraceful,‚Äù and ‚Äúlofty‚Äù as a girl‚Äôs name.

Origin: Vietnamese

Meaning: Graceful

Pronunciation: KUW

Namesakes: Ki·ªÅu Chinh, a Vietnamese-American actress known for The Joy Luck Club (1993).

Popularity: Ki·ªÅu is rare worldwide and mainly used in Vietnam, where it ranked 88th in 2023.

Kim

Kim refers to ‚Äúgold‚Äù or ‚Äúmetal,‚Äù but can also mean ‚Äúbright‚Äù and ‚Äúbeautiful.‚Äù Though a Vietnamese surname, Kim is the most popular Korean surname and appears as Jin in Chinese.

Origin: Vietnamese

Meaning: Gold

Pronunciation: KEEM

Namesakes: Tanya Kim, a Canadian TV personality and the co-host of etalk from 2003 to 2014. Kim Bum-soo, a South Korean singer known for the song I Miss You.

Popularity: Kim is the most popular surname in Korea as of 2023.

L√¢m

L√¢m describes a ‚Äúwood‚Äù or ‚Äúforest,‚Äù while its Mandarin variant is Lin. It‚Äôs often a surname for Chinese populations in southern China and Hong Kong, especially those who speak Cantonese.

Origin: Vietnamese

Meaning: Woods

Pronunciation: LAAM

Variations: Lamm

Namesakes: L√¢m Nh·∫≠t Ti·∫øn, a Vietnamese-American singer with Asia Entertainment Inc. from 1994 to 2016. Lam Thi My Da, a Vietnamese poet, awarded the State Prize for Literature and Arts in 2007.

Popularity: L√¢m is rare worldwide and primarily used in Vietnam, where it ranked 25th in 2023.

L√£nh

L√£nh means ‚Äúcold‚Äù in Chinese but describes a ‚Äúgood,‚Äù ‚Äúfavorable,‚Äù or ‚Äúgentle‚Äù person. It also serves as a nickname for a ‚Äúhappy person‚Äù in Vietnam.

Origin: Vietnamese, Chinese

Meaning: Gentle, king

Pronunciation: LAEYN

Popularity: L√£nh is rare worldwide and primarily used in Vietnam, ranking 332nd in 2023.

L√™

In Vietnam, L√™ is a royal and noble name inspired by the 15th-century L√™ Dynasty. It‚Äôs ranked in the top four Vietnamese surnames of Mandarin or Cantonese speakers. It means ‚Äúdepend on‚Äù in Chinese as Lai, the name of a state in the Henan province.

Origin: Vietnamese, Chinese

Meaning: L√™ dynasty

Pronunciation: LEAY

Namesakes: L√™ VƒÉn Thi√™m, a Vietnamese scientist called the father of Vietnam Mathematics. L√™ Quang Li√™m, a Vietnamese chess grandmaster who won the Asian Chess Championship in 2019.

Popularity: L√™ is currently the third most common surname in Vietnam.

L√™ Ngoc

Though Ngoc means ‚Äújade‚Äù as a girl‚Äôs name, it‚Äôs made up of ‚ÄúL√™,‚Äù inspired by the 15th-century L√™ Dynasty. On its own, Ngoc also means ‚Äúprecious.‚Äù

Origin: Vietnamese

Meaning: Jade

Pronunciation: Leh-NYOK

Variations: Le-Ngoc

Popularity: L√™ Ngoc is very rare worldwide, and its popularity statistics are unknown.

L√™ Th√°nh

L√™ Th√°nh is linked with Chinese last names as with other Vietnamese surnames. It means ‚Äúto succeed,‚Äù ‚Äúfinish, to complete,‚Äù or ‚Äúto accomplish.‚Äù L√™ Th√°nh also means ‚Äúall right‚Äù and ‚Äúbrilliant.‚Äù

Origin: Vietnamese, Chinese

Meaning: Brilliant

Pronunciation: Leh-TAAN

Variations: Lethanh

Namesakes: L√™ Th√°nh T√¥ng, the Vietnamese emperor of ƒê·∫°i Vi·ªát from 1460 to 1497. L√™ Thanh T√∫, a Vietnamese chess player who won the Vietnamese Women‚Äôs Chess Championship in 2008.

Popularity: L√™ Th√°nh is extremely rare worldwide and was used by 1 in 662 million people in 2014.

Linh

Linh derives from the Chinese ‚Äúling,‚Äù meaning ‚Äúsoul‚Äù and ‚Äúspirit.‚Äù As a girl‚Äôs name, it also means ‚Äúblooming flower.‚Äù

Origin: Vietnamese, Chinese

Meaning: Soul

Pronunciation: LIHNG

Variations: Ling

Namesakes: Linh Quang Vi√™n, a Vietnamese soldier known for his role as Lieutenant General in the Army of the Republic of Vietnam.

Popularity: Linh is rare worldwide and mainly used in Vietnam, where it ranked 77th in 2023.

L√¥

L√¥ means ‚Äúto sift,‚Äù but also carries other meanings, from ‚Äúrice vessel‚Äù to the ‚Äúdescendants of Luo.‚Äù Luo was a feudal state existing under the ancient Chinese Shang dynasty.

Origin: Vietnamese, Chinese

Meaning: To sift

Pronunciation: LOH

Variations: Luo

Namesakes: Lo Chih-Chiang, a Taiwanese member of the Kuomintang from 2010 to 2013. Bernard Lo, a Canadian TV anchor on CNBC Asia.

Popularity: L√¥ is considered uncommon in Vietnam, and its exact rankings are unknown.

Lu

Lu appears as Lo in Cantonese, where it means ‚Äú‚Äùrude‚Äù or ‚Äúfoolish.‚Äù It denotes the Chinese state of Lu and ranked 52nd in China in 2002.

Origin: Vietnamese, Chinese

Meaning: State of Lu

Pronunciation: LUW

Variations: Lo

Namesakes: Lu Lan, a Chinese badminton player who won the 2004 Polish Open. Lu Shaye, the Chinese ambassador to France and Monaco since 2019.

Popularity: Lu is rare worldwide and primarily used in Vietnam, ranking 97th in 2023.

Luong

Luong relates to the 6th-century Liang Dynasty and is the Vietnamese variation of Liong and Leong. It means ‚Äúbridge‚Äù or ‚Äúroof beam‚Äù and is occasionally associated with the Chinese Long, meaning ‚Äúdragon.‚Äù

Origin: Vietnamese, Chinese

Meaning: Bridge

Pronunciation: LUW-Ohng

Variations: Liang

Namesakes: L∆∞∆°ng B√≠ch H·ªØu, a Chinese-Vietnamese pop singer with the girl group H.A.T. L∆∞∆°ng Kim ƒê·ªãnh, a Vietnamese catholic philosopher known for Authentic Vietnamese Confucianism.

Popularity: Luong is rare worldwide and mostly used in Vietnam, where it ranked 24th in 2023.

Vietnamese Family Names FAQs

What Are Three Common Vietnamese Last Names?

Nguyen is overwhelmingly the most common among Vietnamese last names, used by about 40% of Vietnamese people. It comes from the Chinese ‚Äúruan,‚Äù referring to a Chinese stringed instrument. Other common Vietnamese surnames include Le, Tran, Pham, and Hoang. In Vietnam, only 14 surnames account for over 90% of the population.

Are Vietnamese Last Names First?

Vietnamese last names are arranged with the surname first, followed by the middle name (if any), and the given name last. This is referred to as the ‚Äúeastern name order.‚Äù Vietnamese family names are passed down from parents and used by all siblings the same way they are in other countries.

Why Do Vietnamese Have Chinese Last Names?

Vietnamese surnames first appeared in 111 BCE, when the Chinese Han Dynasty began their occupation of Vietnam for one thousand years, until around 939 CE. This greatly affected the number of Vietnamese last names with Chinese origins. The naming order that includes using the surname first also came from this thousand-year Chinese occupation.

Maryana Vestic is a Brooklyn-based writer, editor, and food photographer with a background in entertainment Business Affairs. She studied film at NYU, Irish Theatre Studies at Trinity College Dublin, and has an MFA in Creative Writing Nonfiction from The New School. She loves cooking, baking, hiking, and horror films, as well as running a local baking business in Brooklyn with her boyfriend.
